node.text:
One of the best things about homemade fire cider is that every herbalist has their own recipe, which can be adjusted according to taste or the kind of wellness support needed. With fire cider, more than perhaps any other herbal remedy, a recipe is *merely a suggestion.* If you need a starting place, though, enjoy this Fire Cider Making tutorial! 

#firecider #herbalism #herbalist #apothecary #herbalacademy #myherbalstudies

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Herbal Academy in Herbal Academy. May be an image of text that says 'HIBISCUS Herbal Cooler INGREDIENTS 1/4 cup hibiscus 1/4 cup chamomile 2 tablespoons rosehips 1 tablespoon cinnamon chips (using dried ingredients) SRBAL NTERNATIONA ACADAT MERON ERUAL ART5 Η 2011'.

node.text:
"Along the river’s summer walk,
The withered tufts of asters nod;
And trembles on its arid stalk
the hoar plum of the golden-rod."
– John Greenleaf Whittier 
​
​These are the dog days of summer, and the heat of July can be a challenge for many. Hot, humid weather can exacerbate those with a fiery nature and hot constitution. It can make one crabby or just plain uncomfortable! When the thermometer hits the high end and humidity hangs in the air, we all seek a little relief. 🥵 
​
​Fortunately, cooling herbal drinks are a great summer ally to help us roll with the heat. Save this one for your recipe box! 🗂️ 

​HIBISCUS HERBAL COOLER
​
¼ cup dried hibiscus
¼ cup dried chamomile
2 tablespoons dried rosehips
1 tablespoon dried cinnamon chips

​Directions:  Blend herbs together in a 4-quart saucepan. Pour 8 cups (64 ounces) water over herbs, bring water to a boil before turning heat to low. Simmer for 30 minutes.
​
​Alternately, place herbs in a ½ gallon jar, add drinking water, cap, and place in the sun for several hours. Add honey to sweeten, if desired, shake well, and chill in refrigerator. ​Enjoy by the refreshing glass! 🍹 
​
What's in your cup this morning? 
​
​.
​.
​.
​
​#HerbalDrinks #BotanicalDrinks #HerbalRecipe #Hibiscus #Chamomile #SummerSips #Herbalist #Herbalism #HerbalAcademy #TeaTime #JohnGreenleafWhittier

node.accessibility_caption: Purple plates of botanical tamales decorated with flowers and plants

node.text:
VEGAN BOTANICAL TAMALES with HIBISCUS JACKFRUIT FILLING 🌺🌱
​
Show off your flair for using herbs, spices, and edible flowers! We're welcoming @loriastern over on the blog to share this amazing vegan tamales recipe, a fun herbal twist on traditional tamales! 
​
​We love how the edible flower colors and shapes appear to be painted on the masa after steaming. The spiced and hibiscus-infused jackfruit is a pleasing plant-based close companion in taste and texture to carnitas. You might find it more refreshing as a light alternative, for hot weather, lighter fare, or a plant-based diet. Enjoy with rice and beans and a crisp salad.  

​VEGAN BOTANICAL TAMALES
​
For the Hibiscus Jackfruit Filling:

2 tbsp. dried hibiscus flowers
1 tbsp. extra-virgin olive oil
1 medium yellow onion (8 oz.) thinly sliced
2 garlic cloves, finely minced
1 tsp. medium jalapeño (2 oz.), seeds and pith removed, finely chopped
20-oz. can young jackfruit in brine, drained, and broken up into shreds
1⁄2 tsp. kosher salt
1 tsp. chili powder
1 tsp. ground cumin
1 tsp. dried Mexican oregano
1 smoked paprika
Fresh lime juice
Cayenne pepper or ground chipotle chile (optional)

For the Tamales:

18 corn husks
3 1⁄2 cups masa harina
1 tbsp. kosher salt
1 tsp. baking powder
3 cups vegetable stock
1⁄4 cup extra-virgin olive oil
1 cup assorted edible flowers, washed and patted dry (including brightly colored pansies, violas, sunflower petals, nasturtium blooms, and marigolds), mixed with soft, fresh herbs (such as cilantro, parsley, chervil, or tarragon)
Salsa or hot sauce, for serving (optional)

​Stop by the blog to find the recipe directions PLUS a break down of the ingredients that typically garner a lot of questions – and as herbalists, you’ll want all the answers! 
​
Comment with your favorite botanical emoji to give this recipe some love! 🌼🌿🌺🌱 

​

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Herbal Academy in Herbal Academy with @hessaalajmani. May be an image of flower.

node.text:
Saturdays are for shares, so we are spotlighting the stunning work of talented artist, @hessaalajmani: 

"​These ‘Drink Your Medicine’ Arabic coffee cups feature handpicked plants and wildflowers native to the UAE as well as homegrown herbs and flowers. It took a whole season to prepare them..." ​🌻🌿🥀
​
​It looks like this set sold out, but we'll be watching the shop to follow future releases! 👀 

​Join in the #SaturdayShare and post some of your favorite botanical artists in the comments. We want to see!
​
​.
​.
​.
​#botanicalart #Herbalist #Herbalism #Botanicalartist #DrinkYourMedicine #teacup #wildflowers #inspiredsaturdays

node.text:
𝒩𝒶𝓉𝓊𝓇𝒶𝓁 𝒟𝓎𝑒 𝐹𝓁𝑜𝓌𝑒𝓇 𝑀𝒶𝑔𝒾𝒸⁣ ✨
Join Herbal Academy student and blog contributor @pantrypotions for this botanical adventure in how to bundle dye fabric with flowers & spices!

In her own words:
⁣
“I can’t get over the end result. The magic, the beauty. The flowers kiss the fabric leaving a stain of pure art. You have to try this! ⁣
⁣
After prepping the fabric (check my reels for part one), the fun begins. A blank canvas awaits and the designs are endless. ⁣
⁣
Here’s what I did: ⁣
⁣
✨ material: I used a variety - 100% cotton, 100% rayon and a linen / cotton blend. ⁣
⁣
✨ sprinkle flowers both dried or fresh, spices and even kitchen waste like red onion skins! I personally used: dried roses, dried calendula, dried hibiscus (this one really pops), dried leaves (these ones not so much), wilted purple aster, garden picked blue cornflower, and turmeric.⁣
⁣
✨ for smaller fabric, roll, then fold into a bun. Wrap tightly with a rubber band or twine. For larger fabric pieces, fold first then roll & wrap. ⁣
⁣
✨ place fabric in a steamer pot (I read you can insert a colander into a stock pot if you don’t have a steamer). Make sure you have enough water for a long steam, but don’t allow the water to touch the fabric. Steam for an hour with the lid on. ⁣
⁣
✨ half way through, turn your fabric bundles over. Once the hour is up, let your fabric rest and cool down a bit. ⁣
⁣
✨ unwrap and shake off all the plant material⁣
⁣
✨ do not rinse (just yet), keep out of direct sunlight. In a couple days, after the plant dye cures, then you can rinse / wash your fabric with a gentle cleanser. ⁣
⁣
Each piece is one of a kind, beautiful and is like an abstract painting of nature! I love the whole flowers that imprinted and came through on the fabric. Can’t wait to make a beautiful robe next 💐✨⁣”

Have you ever tried botanical dyes? And which piece would you like to try this on? 🌸

#HerbalAcademyReelFun

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Herbal Academy on July 22, 2021. May be an image of flower.

node.text:
After last week's Team Wild or Team Garden poll, we realize most of us here are simply Team Flower! 🌼🌺🍃🌸🌱 And with summer's abundance of wild and garden fresh blooms, now is a perfect time to preserve these beautiful botanicals for future display and enjoyment! 
​
​Once you've harvested the plants of your choice, you’ll need to press them to remove moisture and retain the plant’s color and shape. You can use a dedicated plant press (this one is handmade) or you can just as easily put the plant material inside a phone book, dictionary, your HA textbooks, or other large book. Protect the pages of the book from becoming stained by sandwiching your plant specimens between two pieces of blotting paper, brown butcher paper, newspaper, or even plain-old computer paper. 

Be careful not to overlap your plant specimens within the press or book, which can make them dry in odd shapes. If using a press, then after it is filled you will want to tighten the straps or bolts and set the press aside for 3 to 4 weeks during which the plants can dry without interruption. If using a book, then close the book and weigh it down with a brick or other heavy weight. Let it sit for 3 to 4 weeks for the plants to dry thoroughly.

However you wish to enjoy your beautifully pressed plants is up to you! Search the blog for "How To Make Framed Botanicals to Decorate Your Home" via @hannah_aften for some ideas!
​ 
🌼 ​Have you pressed flowers before? If so, what are your favorite botanicals (wild or garden) to press?
​
​.
​.
​.
​.
​#plantpress #PressedFlowers #Wildflowers #GardenFlowers #Floral #FlowerHarvest #Herbalist #HerbalAcademy #PlantDecor #Botanical #BotanicalCrafts

node.text:
👑 Hail to the Queen! 👑 
​
​Some call her the queen of herbs, which is quite fitting, seeing how this herb is named after a queen. Others call the plant wild carrot due to it's edible, carrot-flavored root, and others sometimes refer to this plant as bird’s nest because, as the flowers age, they curl upward looking like a cupped bird’s nest. Queen Anne’s lace does have a lot of names! QAL not only grows prolifically (especially this time of the year for many of us), so there’s no worry about overharvesting, it also has so many beneficial wellness uses. 
​
​Let's talk about cardiovascular benefits as starters!
​
With its pungent, aromatic, stimulating properties, Queen Anne’s lace works to increase circulatory blood flow. While this makes it a useful “memory-enhancing” herb for brain support and is likely the underlying reason why it stimulates the kidneys, its circulatory stimulating property also makes it a great emmenagogue—an herb that brings on delayed menses. 

To use Queen Anne’s lace as an emmenagogue, a quart infusion of the seeds is used and drank each day until menses begins. As with all emmenagogue herbs, it’s imperative that a person be certain they are not pregnant before using this herb as it can result in loss of pregnancy.

Because of Queen Anne’s lace’s aromatics and stimulating properties, this plant may be useful as a diaphoretic to gently lower temperature when a fever is present. While there aren’t many documented sources citing Daucus carota being used this way, it’s energetic qualities and herbal actions suggest it could be useful in this manner.

CARDIOVASCULAR TAKEAWAY: Queen Anne’s lace stimulates circulatory blood flow throughout the body.
 
Note: Because Queen Anne's lace has poisonous look-alikes, it’s vitally important that you properly identify this botanical if you’re foraging for any part of the plant. Search "queen anne's lace" on our blog for lots of helpful guidance on foraging as well as folklore, further uses, and recipes! 
​
👑 ​Tell us: is Queen Anne's lace blooming in your area right now?
​
#QueenAnnesLace #WildCarrot #PlantProfile #Herbarium #WildForaged #CardiovascularBenefits #Herbalism #HerbNerd #Foraging #WildWeeds

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Herbal Academy on July 20, 2021. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
Today we official open the doors of our heartfelt, important Holistic Cancer Care Course! ☀️ 
​ 
The hard truth is that none of us can predict our future health or the wellbeing of our loved ones, no matter how much we prioritize natural health and wellness. Nor can we predict how we’ll respond if gut-wrenching news knocks on our door. 

🔅 Will we gather our strength and muster our courage?
🔅 Will we pore through books and websites, hungrily looking for anything that may help?
🔅 ​Will we call in our support network to weave their web of love?
🔅 ​Most importantly, will we choose unyielding HOPE over fear? 

It's not an easy journey. Life is not either/or...
​
🔅 ​​We can be tired and also strong.
🔅 ​​We can be afraid and also courageous.
🔅 ​​We can be sick and also hopeful.

We created this heartfelt, in-depth resource so that you can have all the most up-to-date information about holistic cancer care—including clinically tested herbs, nourishing recipes, expert recommendations, trusted lifestyle adjustments, and more—in one place.
​
​Most importantly, we created this course bring you HOPE! 
​
​Learn all about the Holistic Cancer Care Course using the link in our profile!

​
​.
​.
​.
#CancerCommunity #HolisticCancer #HolistiCancerCareCourse #HerbalAcademy #MarleneAdelmann  #CancerThriver #CancerResources #CancerCare #CancerSupport ​#HopeInCancer

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Herbal Academy on July 18, 2021 tagging @krissmacd, and @herbalacademy. May be an image of rose and text that says 'Wild Gar den'.

node.text:
Are you TEAM WILD 🌱🌸 or TEAM GARDEN 🌹🌼 ?

​WILD: Scabiosa atropurpurea, Lavatera cretica and trimestris (Mallows), Cistus crispus (Rock rose), Daucus carota, Papaver rhoeas (Poppy), Echium plantagineum ( Purple Vipers bugloss - but here including a beautiful pinkish one), Trifolium stellatum (Star clover), Crown daisies, Mantisalca salmantica, Carduncellus monspelliensium, Convolvulus althaeoides (Pink bindweed), Centaurium erythraea (common centaury), Anchusia azurea (large blue alkanet).

​GARDEN: Roses, Gerbera, Geranium, Red Valerian, Red flax, Callistemon, Gaillardia, Ceonothus, Salvia, Scabious, Abutilon, Loquat fruit (Nespera) and Wweet peas 
​
📷: by talented #botanicaldreamers photographer @krissmacd
​
​.
​.
​.
​.
​#wildflowers #gardenflowers #flowergarden #floral #beautydaily #herbalist #naturesdelight #theartofslowliving #aquietstyle #botanicalskincare

node.text:
Have you had a chance to stop by the Goods Shop to check out our sweet moving sale deals, *new* Perfectly Imperfect Shop and never before seen, limited-availability items? 
​
​Here's what's currently IN STOCK, but items are going quick: 

​PLANT STEWARD TOTE BAG – 50% off
​This 15x15” 100% Cotton Canvas tote bag will spread that message of plant stewardship. It comes with our plant steward pin and an informational insert.
​*Find it in the Goods Shop!

​​BOTANICAL SKIN CARE RECIPE BOOK – 50% off
​The Herbal Academy’s complete, convenient, illustrative recipe book features 194 tried-and-tested, herbalist-approved body care recipes using herbs and natural ingredients. Snag up a returned order or a copy with minor printing variation, and get your hands on this popular recipe book at 1/2 off!
*Find it in the Perfectly Imperfect Shop
​
​​​PLANT STEWARD PIN – ​$0.99
Wear this message and pin-on button with pride to show the three tenets of being a plant steward: Steward wild plant populations. Grow or source sustainably grown. Choose alternatives.
​*NEW Product, find it in the Goods Shop!
​
SINGLES LAMINATED FERMENTATION RECIPE GUIDE: WATER KEFIR – $2.99
Presented on laminated paper, these recipes will become your go-to guides when making herbal fermentations! You can now purchase each fermentation process separately with our singles options!
​*Find it in the Perfectly Imperfect Shop
​
​5-PIECE BOTTLE BUNDLE SET – $7.99
All herbalists need vessels for their creations. This bundle includes 1 4 oz cobalt glass bottle with spray top, 4 1 oz amber glass bottles & droppers, and a Crest Muslin Bag.
​​*NEW Product, find it in the Goods Shop!

MEN'S + WOMEN'S CREST TEE SHIRT – 50% off
Our super comfy, timeless heather grey tees are 100% Organic Cotton. Take pride in your school by wearing the HA Crest close to your heart!
​*Find it in the Goods Shop!
​
​​A BIG thanks for helping us clean house this week in pre for our upcoming move! The PERFECTLY IMPERFECT SHOP was especially a big hit... shall we do it again sometime? 
​
​
​#SecondsShop #HerbalProducts #PlantStewardship #Herbalist #HerbalAcademy #MyHerbalStudies #Apothecary #Herbalism #BotanicalSkinCare #Fermentation

node.text:
🌿🌱🍃 HOW TO DRY FRESH HERBS USING A DEHYDRATOR 🌿🌱🍃 
​
​Summer is the season of abundance. The days are long, the plants are growing, flowers blooming, and the bees buzzing and dancing in the air. 
​
​It can be easy to take this abundance for granted, but of course, the world turns, the seasons change, and once again winter will descend upon us. We are fortunate that we can preserve our abundant summer herb harvest for the winter months. 
​
​Historically, herbs were dried in small bundles, hanging in kitchens and attics. The natural beauty and aroma of this method are certainly enjoyable. But sometimes you may not have the space or the long drying time needed for hanging herbs. Introducing: the dehydrator method...
​
​THE STEP-BY-STEP: 

🌱 ​Preheat dehydrator between 95 and 115 degrees F. If you live in a particularly humid climate, you may want to set your temperature as high as 125 degrees. 

​🌱 Gently blot damp herbs dry with a towel to remove as much moisture as you can.  

​🌱 Place the herbs on the dehydrator trays in a single layer.  Small leaves can remain on the stems, but removing larger leaves from thick stems will shorten the drying time. 
​If you are using a stacked dehydrator, place the harder-to-dry herbs on the bottom and the lighter herbs on the top. It will be easier to remove the faster-drying herbs if they are on top. 
​
🌱 Check your herbs periodically for dryness. ​Drying times will vary depending on the moisture content of your herbs. Loose, fine herbs like yarrow and mint will dry more quickly than moisture-filled herbs like plantain or comfrey. Expect 1-4 hours for most herbs. 

🌱 The herbs are dry when the leaves crumble and the stems break when bent. 
​ 
🌱 After you remove the herbs from the dehydrator, allow them to cool before storing to avoid condensation forming.  Of course, label, label, label! 
​
Who's tried the dehydrator method for drying herbs? Any tips we missed including? 
​PS: ​A note about drying roots in the comments! 
​
​#DryingHerbs #Preservation #HerbHarvest #DriedHerbs #PreservingTheHarvest #Herbalism #Herbalist #Apothecary #SummerHarvest #HerbalAcademy #MyHerbalStudies

node.text:
🍄 "Nature alone is antique, and the oldest art a mushroom." ​–Thomas Carlyle 
​
Experiences + 📸  by HA student, @the.durt.family:
​"I’m sure by now you’ve heard us use the term “students of the world” to describe our current family mission. By this, we mean both students of the true physical earth, as well as students seeking out teachers, wisdom, and guidance.

Being with a toddler while dwelling in the forest means we spend a majority of our day active: exploring the landscape, throwing rocks into creeks, collecting pine cones. However, early in the morning, before our daughter awakes, and later in the evening, when she eventually falls asleep, Matthew and I have been learning to stand still, reflect, and explore all different types of literature. Most recently, I started an online course through @herbalacademy . Up here in the Rocky Mountains, we are surrounded by so many medicinal plants; our campsite, in particular, is abundant with wild roses and yarrow. But something even more curious grows all around us, something shrouded in lore and mystery: mushrooms.

Since we are wandering deep in the woods for these first few months of our retreat, it seemed appropriate to become more familiar with these odd creatures. My knowledge of mushrooms before I started this course was vague and scattered. I knew they lived in large underground networks, spanning whole forests, existing in a symbiotic relationship with trees. And I ALSO knew they make portals that transport you to fairyland. 🧚‍♀️ Beyond this, I am finding there is much more to be learned.

This course is in-depth spanning the lore, foraging practices, anatomy, biology, health benefits, & how to prepare extracts. It contains written lessons and insightful videos, and the course even comes with a foraging kit containing morphology cards to help you identify mushrooms you come across while exploring the woods." 🍄 

Fascinated by the mysterious mushroom world? Stop by The Mushroom Course, your complete guide for learning all about the compelling world of fungi – from cap to stem! [Link to courses in our profile]
